mxCell.value: Let's Begin

<<Accounts>>

Welcome [[user_first_name]] to MyBudgetCoach! 

MyBudgetCoach is a unique budgeting software that comes along with a virtual avatar. You selected, me, Spencer Stephenson, as your personal coach. I look forward to helping you start a new phase of your journey to financial wellness!

<<Accounts>>

My avatar will walk you through the setup tutorial. It's not a chat bot and cannot answer your questions directly, but does have a message center where you can ask questions about the app. You can click the back button to review as needed, or click "Manage Coach" and then "Reset Coach" to go back to the start of the tutorial.

<<Accounts>>

If at any time you reach a point where you would like a one-on-one coaching session with me, please select the "Schedule Video Call" link to the left and select a time that works for you.
Heck yeah!

<<Accounts>>

Please note that the one-on-one sessions do have an additional charge on top of your MyBudgetCoach Subscription. You do get a discounted rate compared to my traditional budget coaching rate.
move_to: zoom_link
That is reassuring.

<<Accounts>>

MyBudgetCoach is a budgeting software similar to an online envelope system. 

This means it will only allow you to budget money that you currently have. When first starting to budget this way it can be frustrating, but as your coach I will be here helping you the whole way!
Let's Begin.

<<Accounts>>

Let's take the first step together. Here's the breakdown of what we'll walk through in the tutorial. 
1. Account Tour and Set Up
2. How to Add Transactions
3. Trusting Your Numbers
4. Budget Tour and Set Up
5. Budget Skills
I renamed my budget.

<<Accounts>>

Everything is custom here, so let's start with what you'll call your budget. 

Click on the dropdown arrow and select "Rename Budget". Then pick a name for your budget. Make sure you press "Enter". you can change it later if needed.
move_to: budget_name
Ask away!

<<Accounts>>

To help me better understand your personalized situation, I want to ask you some questions about your household.
Yes, I have a partner.
No, it's just me.

<<Accounts>>

Are you budgeting with a partner?

Next
partner_name = [user_input]

<<Accounts>>

Great! I love that you guys are pursuing this together. What is their first name?

<<Accounts>>

Understood! This set up process will be a little quicker.

<<Accounts>>

Thanks for sharing [[user_first_name]]. I look forward to working with you and [[partner_name]] throughout the tutorial!
Single Account
Multiple Accounts

<<Accounts>>

Do you and [[partner_name]] have a single account where all income is deposited or separate accounts?
Just one
2 or more!

<<Accounts>>

How many checking accounts do you use?

<<Accounts>>

Great! We will get this set up!

<<Accounts>>

Sounds good! We can get all these add for you!
I have my info! Let's get started.

<<Accounts>>

For this step you will need to log in to your bank and see the current balance of your account. Come back to me when you have the current balance of all your accounts.

<<Accounts>>

Easy enough! Let's go ahead and add that account.

<<Accounts>>

We can handle this no problem. I will have you had them all once after I show you how to add the first one. I recommend starting with the most used checking account.

<<Accounts>>

If you are wanting to automatically add transactions. Click "Start a New Conversation" on the left-hand side and start the "Import Transaction" Conversation. To manually add accounts, click Next.

<<Accounts>>

To manually add your account click "+ Add account".
I did it!

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account". Name your account, select "For Budget: Checking" and then enter the current balance of that account. Click "Create" to finish.
move_to: add_account

<<Accounts>>

Do you have any pending transactions in your account?

<<Accounts>>

No problem! We will come back and revisit this later.

<<Accounts>>

Do you have any credit cards that you use regularly?

<<Accounts>>

We will add your credit cards now.

<<Accounts>>

Great! I will still teach you the steps just in-case you decide to use one later.
I have the balance.

<<Accounts>>

Just like the checking account you'll need to login to your bank and get the current balance. Move on to the next steps once you have the current balance!
All done!

<<Accounts>>

Select "+ Add Account". Click "Create Local Account", name your account, select "For Budget: Credit Card" and then enter your balance. Click "Create" to finish.

<<Accounts>>

Do any of your cards have any pending transactions?

<<Accounts>>

Thank you for the information. We will teach you the basics now that we have your accounts added.

<<Accounts>>

Thank you. We will circle back to these pending transactions soon.
I've selected it!

<<Accounts>>

For now, on the left side of the screen, click on the checking account you have added and named.
I can see the totals

<<Accounts>>

Below the name you can see the account balance. Click here to see the breakdown of cleared and uncleared totals.
move_to: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

I'll explain more shortly, but first we will finish our tour.

<<Accounts>>

This button lets you upload a CSV file of your bank transactions. This is totally optional.
move_to: import_button

<<Accounts>>

If you get through setup and want to use this option, I can help you with that later.

<<Accounts>>

This is where you manually add new transactions for this account.
move_to: add_new_button
I have reviewed.

<<Accounts>>

The "Filter" button lets you view transactions based on certain criteria you set. Click it to view your options.
move_to: filter_button

<<Accounts>>

The "Search" bar helps you find transactions based on date, category, transaction amount, or payee.
move_to: search_bar

<<Accounts>>

Sometimes you may want to "Split" transactions. For example, Costco has both cleaning supplies and food.

<<Accounts>>

MyBudgetCoach allows you to enter this into one transaction and then split this into two categories or more.

<<Accounts>>

These arrows allow you to expand or collapse split transactions. You can collapse them for easier view or you can leave them open for the full picture.
move_to: split_toggle_button

<<Accounts>>

You have even more options here. Click this and explore.
move_to: more_button

<<Accounts>>

By clicking "Show running balance", a new column is added to the right. This shows the account balance after each transaction occurs. It will be useful when reconciling the account.

<<Accounts>>

'Hide "cleared" checkboxes' removes the column that shows the cleared (green) and uncleared (gray) checkboxes next to your transactions.

<<Accounts>>

With "Export" you can download all of your transactions as a CSV file. This is not necessary for most users but can be helpful if you want a more in-depth view of your data.

<<Accounts>>

"Link Account" is a feature that allows you to connect MyBudgetCoach to your bank so that transactions import automatically. Check out the SimpleFin conversation for more details on how to use this feature.

<<Accounts>>

"Close Account" will be used if you no longer need to see an account in MyBudgetCoach. This is where you can delete it. Note: this button will not affect your actual bank account in real life only the view in MyBudgetCoach.
I'm ready to learn more!

<<Accounts>>

We have finished the tour of the account page. Remember to take a break if needed. I will be right here when you come back. You are killing it so far!

<<Accounts>>

We have finished step 1. Let's move on to the next step. 

1. Account Tour and Set Up
2. How to Add Transactions
3. Trusting Your Numbers
4. Budget Tour and Set Up
5. Budget Skills

<<Accounts>>

Let's practice adding transactions to your account. Start by verifying you are on your checking account.

<<Accounts>>

Click on "+ Add New" at the top.
I have my payee entered!

<<Accounts>>

Now click on "Payee" and enter "Grocery Store". Since we are starting from scratch, click "+ Create New Payee".

<<Accounts>>

In the note, add "Test" so we know to delete this later. This note section is great for leaving memos for yourself.

<<Accounts>>

Click on Category and select Food. You can type "F" and it will filter through the budget categories. You can also scroll through the category choices.

<<Accounts>>

Since you spent money, it's considered a payment. Type $50 in the payment box.
I have added the transaction!

<<Accounts>>

To save this transaction, press "Add".
I cancelled the next transaction.

<<Accounts>>

Notice that one you added one transaction, MyBudgetCoach assumes you immediately want to add another transaction. For now, click cancel to move forward.

<<Accounts>>

Nice work! You added your first transaction. Now, let's look at a few more elements of MyBudgetCoach.

<<Accounts>>

When you add a new transaction the system defaults to "Uncleared". The checkbox is gray indicating that the transaction has not cleared your bank account yet.
I cleared the transaction.

<<Accounts>>

Let's pretend you checked your account, and the transaction has cleared. Click this box to turn it green and "Clear" the transaction.

<<Accounts>>

Let's try one more thing and pretend you had some money come into the account. This could be your paycheck or even refunds.

<<Accounts>>

If you're starting to understand the program, feel free to add the transaction on your own. I will still guide you just in case you get stuck.

<<Accounts>>

Start by clicking "+ Add New".
Paycheck entered!

<<Accounts>>

For this test entry, enter the below data and then click Add. 

Payee: Employer
Note: Test
Category: Income
Deposit: $500

You can scroll or type "I" to find the income category.

<<Accounts>>

You now have two transactions. One cleared and one uncleared. You should be able to see the totals of each. If not, click on your account balance.
It's cleared!

<<Accounts>>

The "uncleared total" is $500. Now, click on the grey checkmark for the paycheck you entered and clear this transaction.

<<Accounts>>

The "cleared total" now matches the account balance and the "uncleared" total is 0.

<<Accounts>>

This "Cleared" versus 
"Uncleared" portion, is important for if you have spent money, but it hasn't hit your account yet. AKA the pending transactions we mentioned earlier.

<<Accounts>>

You can leave these transactions tracked in MyBudgetCoach, but leave them grey until it clears the bank. At that time, you can mark them green.

<<Accounts>>

Let me show you how to delete transactions and we can use these to get rid of the test transactions.

<<Accounts>>

Select the checkboxes next to each transaction. Near the search bar there is a purple text that says "2 transactions". Click this and choose delete.

<<Accounts>>

This process can be a little confusing, but will get easier the more you use the app.
I am on my credit card.

<<Accounts>>

Adding transactions to the credit card is slightly different than the checking account. We will quickly add some credit card transactions to explain the key differences. Please click on your credit card account to get started.

<<Accounts>>

Credit card transactions are backwards of your checking account. Since credit cards are amount you owe when you spend the negative balance will go up and when you pay your payment the amount you owe will go down.
Done and done.

<<Accounts>>

Click "+ Add New" and type "Cell Phone Company" as your payee.
move_to: add_new_button

<<Accounts>>

Add a note labeled "test", for category select "Bills", and enter $100 in the payment box since you spent money on your credit card.

<<Accounts>>

Finish this transaction by pressing the check and clearing it. Since we are only adding one transaction feel free to press cancel.

<<Accounts>>

Notice the account balance is red and is -$100 from your starting balance. This is because you still need to pay the credit card bill when it becomes due.
move_to: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

When you are moving money between accounts in MyBudgetCoach, the payee is very important. Click next to see the options.
I've selected transfer from checking.

<<Accounts>>

There are two groups: "Payees" and "Transfer To/From". Under the transfer option you'll see your checking account. Please click that for your payee.

<<Accounts>>

Notice that you cannot select a category, and the system entered "Transfer". That is because you are simply moving money from checking to pay your credit card bill.

<<Accounts>>

Please enter $100 in the deposit box. Then check the grey box to clear the transactions and press "Add" to finish.

<<Accounts>>

Awesome! You paid $100 toward your credit card. Your account balance for your credit card increases by $100, bringing you back to $0 or your starting balance. Let's see what happened to your checking!

<<Accounts>>

Click into your checking account.
move_to: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

Do you see the new transaction? MyBudgetCoach automatically added it to your checking account and the $100 has been taken from this account and applied to your credit card.

<<Accounts>>

In your checking account, the payee is an arrow and then your credit card name. Pay attention to the direction of the arrow before the account name.

<<Accounts>>

This transaction shows $100 subtracted from this account. The only thing left to do is clear the transaction once it shows up in your bank!
Test transaction deleted.

<<Accounts>>

Let's delete these test transactions. Go ahead and select the checkbox next to the credit card payment. Then click "1 transaction" in the purple at the top and "Delete" using the drop down menu.

<<Accounts>>

Go back to the credit card and look for your transaction. You shouldn't see it. MyBudgetCoach automatically adds/deletes/changes transactions between accounts. If you change one screen MyBudgetCoach changes the other.

<<Accounts>>

Let's make sure we have everything cleared out now that we have learned the basics. Delete all transactions that may still be there. If you need a break now would be a good time before we begin our next section.

<<Accounts>>

Great job so far! You have completed 2 stages. We will now begin stage 3: trusting your numbers. 

1. Account Tour and Set Up
2. How to Add Transactions
3. Trusting your Numbers
4. Budget Tour and Set Up
5. Budget Skills

<<Accounts>>

Before we can budget your dollars, we need to make sure your amounts are correct in your accounts. Let me explain.

<<Accounts>>

I want you to be able to open MyBudgetCoach and trust your numbers. So why might account balances vary?
That makes sense.

<<Accounts>>

When you open your bank app, it will tell you how much you have. Some banks give you the amount including pending transactions, others show you the amount BEFORE those charges clear.

<<Accounts>>

When you enter the amount in your accounts into MBC, we need to know if those pending charges will affect how much you have to budget.

<<Accounts>>

To verify this, I need you to open both MyBudgetCoach and your bank website open. Click next when you have both these open.

<<Accounts>>

In your bank account, does the total available include the pending transactions?

<<Accounts>>

No problem! In this case, we will need to start your balance prior to those pending transactions so once we enter them into MBC you balance will show your current balance.
My account is up to date

<<Accounts>>

Great! This means the amount you entered as the starting balance is correct and you can enter those pending transactions as soon as they clear.

<<Accounts>>

To get the correct starting balance, add up the total of all your pending transactions. Then, Subtract that amount from your account's available balance.
move_to: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

Use this number as your starting balance in MyBudgetCoach. Update your starting balance to this amount so we can make sure we stay accurate with your bank.

<<Accounts>>

This should match the number you just calculated and not your bank account yet.

<<Accounts>>

If your bank has a running total of transactions. Go down to the last cleared transaction in your bank account. Find the running total of the pending transactions. Does this amount match the amount your bank says is available in this account?
My account is up to date

<<Accounts>>

Great! Just add and clear the pending transactions as they get validated by your bank.
My account is up to date

<<Accounts>>

The number you are looking at may already calculate the pending transactions. If you can't get this to match start the "Reconciliation" Conversation for assistance.

<<Accounts>>

Great! This means that your starting balance is accurate. You are good to move forward.

<<Accounts>>

Feel free to go back and add any additional accounts you want. Remember to reconcile these accounts to make sure you are starting at the correct spot. Once all accounts are added press "I'm ready" and we can begin budgeting.

<<Budget>>

Now for the fun part! Creating the budget. In MyBudgetCoach we only allow you to budget the money you actually have. You are not able to forecast money you haven't received yet. This can be tricky for some customers, so I will be here to help you along the way.

<<Budget>>

I'll give you a quick tour of your budget screen. Here you can see the current month as well as previous and future months.

<<Budget>>

If you have added a credit card balance you may see a weird number in the "To Budget", this is fine for now. We will circle back to this after the tour and get this corrected before we move forward.

<<Budget>>

Let's say you want to compare several months at once. Depending on your browser zoom level, you can select up to six months at a time. Please click the third calendar icon.
move_to: calendar_icons

<<Budget>>

Now you can view three months. Let's change the view so you can see a difference set of months using the purple selection.
move_to: months_band

<<Budget>>

Below the current month, there are several pieces of information and an amount labeled "To Budget".
move_to: budget_header

<<Budget>>

While you are getting to know MyBudgetCoach, just focus on the amount to budget for now.

<<Budget>>

Click on the purple number to see some options for this amount. There are multiple ways to move money around your budget. After all, it's meant to be flexible!

<<Budget>>

Let's move onto the next part!

<<Budget>>

This is the budget table, basically a digital cash envelope system! You create categories relevant to your life and budget dollars accordingly.

<<Budget>>

The "Category" column houses the names of each category. We'll get customizing these in a bit.
move_to: category_column
move_to: budgeted_column

<<Budget>>

The "Budgeted" column is where you'll be budgeting your dollars. This shows you what you have allocated each month for the categories.

<<Budget>>

Next up is the "Spent" column. This shows you what you have actually spent out of the budgeted dollars.
move_to: spent_column

<<Budget>>

The last column is "Balance". This shows you what you have available to spend. If it's negative and red, you have overspent in this category. If the amount if black, that is what you have available.
move_to: balance_column

<<Budget>>

If you don't cover the overspending, you either risk over-drafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card. More on this later!

<<Budget>>

The three dots next to "Category" gives you visual options. You can collapse and expand category groups. You can also show and hide "Hidden" categories.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over a row, an arrow appears. You have options to add a category in this group, hide it, rename it, or delete it.

<<Budget>>

Now, add a category to this group. Click that arrow again, and add a category. Choose a regular monthly bill you pay, such as your rent or mortgage. This will be a test and we will delete it later.

<<Budget>>

Great job making it this far. We will really see a budget get built here shortly.

<<Budget>>

My avatar is built so that as you click through the program it will automatically create categories for you.
On my own.
Let's do it together!

<<Budget>>

If you prefer to generate the budget all by yourself click the own my own button. Otherwise, we will work together to build a budget that works for you!

<<Budget>>

Take some time to build your budget and remember you can always click back and we can build the budget together if you prefer. If you get stuck remember the zoom call in the corner. I am happy to work with you to build a great budget.

<<Budget>>

For the organization or the budget, we will generate it with three buckets. Living expenses, Future, and Fun. Each of these will have their own organizational structure within them.

<<Budget>>

The reason I organize the budget like this is because it helps you remember to still save for the future as well as have fun today.

<<Budget>>

To help make sure we stay organized please delete all categories in the budget. Income should be the only one remaining.

<<Budget>>

If you prefer to have the categories in a different order remember you can drag and drop them in whatever order you want.

create_category_group: Monthly Living Expenses
create_category_group: Annual Living Expenses
create_category_group: Variable Living Expenses
create_category_group: Future
create_category_group: Fun Money
create_category_group: Credit Cards

<<Budget>>

The budget should have just updated to have seven groups. (Income, Monthly Living Expenses, Annual Living Expenses, Variable Living Expenses, Future, Fun Money, and Credit Cards). If you see more than these please deleted them by clicking the drop down arrow next to the category name.
2 Incomes, Mine and [[partner_name]]s
I have more income streams than these

<<Budget>>

Now we're going to start building a budget that is personalized to you! How many income streams do you have in the household?

<<Budget>>

Perfect, I have just created an income category using your name.
create_category: Income: [[user_first_name]] Income

<<Budget>>

Now we're going to start building a budget that is personalized to you! How many income streams do you have in the household?

<<Budget>>

Wow Congratulations! Having multiple income streams is a great thing. This does however make it more difficult for me to help you add these. Rather than clicking through a bunch of questions, I think it would be best to manually enter these categories.

<<Budget>>

Perfect, I have created an income category using each of your names.

<<Budget>>

Under the "Income" header, click the drop-down arrow and then "add category". Name this category for whatever you would like to call this income. I like separating each income category. (Ex. Simoleon Substance Income, Pet Sitting Income, Rental Income). Repeat this for all your income streams then press next.
Just one

create_category: Income: [[user_first_name]] Income
create_category: Income: [[partner_name]] Income

<<Budget>>

I have added on more income category called "Other Income" as a catch all for any random income. That was easy! We have our income created. Let's work on our Living Expenses next.
create_category: Income: Other Income

<<Budget>>

For Living Expenses, we want to have these organized in order of date focusing on monthly fixed expenses first and then variable expenses later. This means things that cost the same thing every month will be on top and in order by due date.

<<Budget>>

The way I build my first budget is by looking at all my past expenses over the last month and add them in order by date they occurred. 

For example, my mortgage payment comes out on the first. This would be my first category under Monthly Fixed Expense and would look something like this. (Mortgage due 1st). This quickly allows me to know what this is and what day this is due on.

<<Budget>>

Feel free to add all your fixed monthly expenses. Remember to add the due date to each bill that way you can quickly see when they are due.

<<Budget>>

For the monthly fixed expense category, you should include your debt payments as well. 

This should include the minimum payments for your car loans, student loans, and credit cards. The reason I add them here is so if you ever have a tight month, we know we need to focus on hitting the minimums here first before adding to other categories.

<<Budget>>

I am going to list a few other items that you may have forgotten. If these apply feel free to add them otherwise just skip to the next slide. 

Auto Insurance, Property Insurance, HOA Dues, Life Insurance, Phone Bill, Internet Bill, Electricity, Water, Sewer, Childcare.

<<Budget>>

It looks like you may have all your Monthly Living Expenses added with their due dates. Great job! The next portion is a little tougher since these are not things we see every month but are still out there. That is the Annual Living Expenses. These could include insurances, registrations, professional licenses, subscriptions, and credit card fees.

<<Budget>>

We want you to add everything you can think of that applies to you. That way we can work towards these goals over time. I recommend using the same naming convention and putting the category name and the month this is due. That way you have a quick snapshot of what is due each month.

<<Budget>>

Go ahead and add all the categories you can think of at this point. Remember, we can always add more if they come up later and we will add it for next year to make sure it is part of the plan.

<<Budget>>

Congratulations you have completed your Living Expenses! Nice work. Next, we will move on to your Future section. This section includes Additional Payments on Debts, Emergency Fund Savings, as well as any sinking funds you may have. This should also include investments.

<<Budget>>

Let me take a quick step back here and explain each of these categories. Additional Payments on Debts is exactly what it sounds like. This is a payment on debts over and above your minimum payments. An emergency fund is a fund that is there in case of emergency. We like to plan an emergency fund in order to help us not have to go into debt for emergency expenses.

<<Budget>>

Sinking funds are similar to emergency funds except they are here to plan for known expenses. For example, tires for a vehicle. We know at some point that our car will need new tires. Let's work to fill this prior so that we have the ability to pay for this when it happens.

<<Budget>>

Sinking funds don't just need to be for those sad expenses. They can also be for fun. Let's create a sinking fund for a vacation as well as Christmas gifts!

<<Budget>>

If there are any other sinking funds you can think of at this time feel free to create those categories before moving on. If there is a specific date target for these make sure to include them in the title.

<<Budget>>

For investments, I like making sure I have this as a category so we can track how much we are putting towards them. I do not include 401k since mien withdraws before my paycheck, but I do include Roth IRA contributions, as well as Taxable Brokerage Contributions.

<<Budget>>

Once you have all these categories completed click next and we can move on to my favorite part. The "Fun Money" section.

<<Budget>>

In this section, I include anything that is not essential to live. This includes Entertainment, Dining Out, Gifts, Home Furnishings, Shopping and anything else on which you spend your money.

<<Budget>>

Now let's move on to the variable living expenses. These are the things that vary in price month to month but are still required to live. Groceries, Gas, Personal Care, and Pet Expenses are examples of what should go in this category. These also typically do not have a specific due date.

<<Budget>>

Please create any categories you deem necessary to live. The good thing about personal finance is that it is personal. Here is your chance to decides what matters to you.

<<Budget>>

You can include as little or as much as you want in this section. I personally recommend cutting this to the bare bones starting out and leaving the rest to fun money, but it is up to you.

<<Budget>>

Click next once you have added you variable expenses.

<<Budget>>

You can make these as specific or as broad as you like. I have some clients that split dining out into dine out, fast food, coffee shops, and bars, in order to get a break down of each, while others just want to see the overall category. It is up to you to choose which way you prefer. And remember you can always come back and change this later.

<<Budget>>

Go ahead and add all your categories before moving on to the next section.

<<Budget>>

Credit cards are a little more complicated to set up and not every person has a credit card. If you do, now would be a good time to start the additional conversation called "Add Credit Card". This walks you through the steps of how to add a credit card, handle transactions, and update the budget table. This is the conversation that can help fix the red "To Budget" portion we discussed earlier.

<<Budget>>

To get to this conversation, click manage coach and go down to "Add Credit Card"

<<Budget>>

Now that we have the budget created we are almost completed. We have a few more quick things to talk about and then you are free to budget your dollars.

<<Budget>>

I want you to look at the purple dollars you have available to budget.
move_to: budget_header

<<Budget>>

This is the amount you have to budget and we need to assign them into the categories we have created. There are a few ways to do this. The first way is to click the purple number and select "Move to a category"

<<Budget>>

You'll then enter the amount you want to transfer and select the category. To finish click "Transfer".

<<Budget>>

Another way is to click in the "Budgeted" column for the category and type the amount. Press enter or click out of the box and it saves.

<<Budget>>

The goal is to have zero dollars to budget. This means that every dollar is accounted for. This does not mean that you have zero dollars remaining since you can and should contribute to savings. This will remove it from the "To Budget" since it has a task but will still be there in case of emergency.

<<Budget>>

There are going to be times when your budget doesn't work out as planned. The system will make it clear when you have overspent and will ask you to take money from another category. The "Balance" column will be in red. This means you need to fix the issue.

<<Budget>>

You can move this from a different category that is under spent.

<<Budget>>

If you have money left over in a category at the end of the month, it will roll over into the next month.

<<Budget>>

Since MyBudgetCoach only allows you to budget dollars you have, it is essential to prioritize where you spend your money. The way the budget was set up during our tutorial is in my opinion the order in which you should spend money. Living Expenses first, then Future, and then Fun Money.

<<Budget>>

This is your budget though. You are able to make any changes you want and prioritize your spending on whatever is important to you.

<<Budget>>

If at any point your budget gets off track and you don't know how to fix it, remember you can message me in the message center for a quick opinion. If this is something we can easily fix I will guide you through via messenger.

<<Budget>>

If this is a more complicated issue, I may suggest booking a call and we can discuss this together and work to get you back on track.

<<Budget>>

... one last thing before I leave you to budgeting ...

<<Budget>>

Can you answer 3 short questions for me? I want to make sure I continue to improve how helpful I am!

<<Budget>>

Can you answer 3 short questions for me? I want to make sure I continue to improve how helpful I am!

<<Budget>>

Thanks for that information. Direct Import within MyBudgetCoach has some great benefits. For example, the starting balance for linked accounts is automatically set and the system includes three prior days worth of transactions to get you started.

<<Accounts>>

Direct Import removes the additional tasks of having to manually upload transactions. Each time you log in, the system will automatically have added recent transactions.

<<Accounts>>

MyBudgetCoach uses machine learning, so as you continue to use the system, the system will automatically apply proposed categories to new transactions and the manual steps to categorize transactions will lessen over time.

<<Accounts>>

To increase your security, MyBudgetCoach has partnered with a third-party service, SimpleFIN, to link your accounts. SimpleFIN uses a well-established connection software called 'MX' to connect your bank account financial institutions to SimpleFIN.

<<Accounts>>

To connect SimpleFIN to MyBudgetCoach, there is a one-time code produced by SimpleFIN to enter into MyBudgetCoach. The accounts you link in SimpleFIN will then become available to link to already existing accounts within MyBudgetCoach to start Direct Import.

<<Accounts>>

Please note SimpleFIN does have a small additional fee: $1.50 per month, or $15 per year (not including tax, if applicable). This is paid separately from your MyBudgetCoach subscription and is paid through SimpleFIN, not within MyBudgetCoach.

We need to allow the remaining balance you don't pay off this current month, to continue to future months, since your credit card company will continue to have that balance carry over until you pay it off.

<<Budget>>

MyBudgetCoach has a unique feature that is called 'Rollover overspending.' This option allows a user to have the debt continue into future months, instead of paying off this month, so you can pay it off overtime.

<<Budget>>

Selecting the 'Rollover overspending' option increases your 'To Budget' number in the current month, since the debt has now been rolled over to future months.

<<Budget>>

<<Budget>>

The arrow to the right of the amount in the Balance column is how MyBudgetCoach alerts you to the fact you have rolled over the overspending for future months. This option will stay turned on for all future months, unless you select to 'Remove overspending rollover.'

For me, the easiest place to find the balance we need is in the list of recent transactions. Typically there's a section of pending transactions and below that there's all the cleared transactions. Often beside each cleared transaction it'll show the balance after those transactions. Or sometimes it shows it above each day's list of transactions.

Cleared balance represents cleared transactions and uncleared are pending transactions. When we reconcile we are only concerned with cleared transactions, since pending ones can change.

Find that date in your bank as well as your budget account. Look at your bank and go in the order of the transactions there. Check for each one in your budget and check them off (far left of each transaction) as you find them.

Add any transactions that were missed and delete any that are extras. Fix typos if you find them. Also make sure outflows are in the payment column and inflows in the deposit column.

Now for the fun part! Creating the Budget! In MyBudgetCoach we only allow you to budget the money you actually have, but do not allow you to forecast for money not received yet. This can be tricky for some customers, so I will be here to help you along the way.

<<Budget>>

For the organization of the budget we will generate it with savings at the top, followed by monthly fixed expenses, annual fixed expenses, and variable expenses at the bottom.

<<Budget>>

The reason I organize the budget like this is because paying yourself first is a great method to make sure you are building for your future.

<<Budget>>

If you prefer to have savings at the bottom feel free to delete the category and add it at the bottom.

Trusting Your Numbers

One of the complexities for users with a zero-based budgeting software is the due diligence to ensure the account balances in MyBudgetCoach match the account balances in the financial institution. 

A difficult part of having the accounts match is ensuring the starting balance set by the user at the time the accounts are added are accurate. For checking accounts, some banks include pending transactions in the Current Balance. If the starting balance includes pending transactions, then when the transactions are added, they will be double counted. For credit cards, the Current Balance doesn't include pending transactions, so this is not an issue. 

Coach can consider consulting Coach Trainers to add a flow for verifying starting balance.
Coach should consider adding a flow for walking a user through how to link accounts with SimpleFin. Consult with Coach Trainers if interested in sample flow.
Consider having a question to create a break for the user. Could also reference the earlier list of steps to complete, and show progress by crossing out those pieces that are done.

People who have Credit Card balances in excess of their available dollars in their checking account will have a negative amount To Budgeted. This is an important step for the user, but can be handled in a various number of ways. Consider the main steps the user needs to complete, and then determine as the coach if you want to add more detail for any of those steps:

1) Adding the Credit Card Category Group
2) Add a Category for each Credit Card
3) Changing the category on the account side of the Credit Card starting balance to the newly created Category
4) Rollover overspending if not going to pay off balance

This will give the user back their dollars in their checking account in the To Budgeted.
